questions.text: What is the dose range of lithium in mEq/dL for acute attacks of mania and long-term maintenance?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.6 to 1.5 mEq/dL

 

Lithium has a narrow therapeutic window and its serum concentrations need careful monitoring.

 

0.6 to 1.5 mEq/dL represents the general therapeutic range for lithium. According to 12th edition of Synopsis of Psychiatry,  for acute manic episodes, the target serum lithium level is between 1.0 to 1.2 mEq/dL, while for long-term maintenance, it is 0.4 to 0.8 mEq/dL. The option closes to this range is option C.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.5 to 1 mEq/dL is close but not the typical therapeutic range. It is on the lower end and might not be effective for many patients, especially during acute mania.

 

Option B. 0.1 to 0.5 mEq/dL is subtherapeutic. Such low levels wouldn't be effective for the treatment of bipolar disorder and would not offer the necessary mood-stabilizing effects.

 

Option D. 2 to 3 mEq/dL is a toxic range. Lithium concentrations at this level can result in severe side effects and even life-threatening toxicity.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 655

choices.text: Inside the membrane
At the C-terminal
At the N-terminal
Both inside the membrane and at C- terminal

questions.text: The signaling sequence in a type 2 membrane protein with N-terminal facing cytoplasm is located in?(INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inside the membrane

 

The signaling sequence in a type 2 membrane protein is located inside the membrane.

 

These sequences usually have methionine as the terminal amino acid.

 

Transmembrane proteins are integral proteins that span across the plasma/ endoplasmic reticulum (ER) membrane. They are classified into types 1 to 4. –

 

Type 1 membrane proteins have a cleavable N-terminal signal sequence outside the cell, a transmembrane sequence that is usually situated close to the C-terminus and the C-terminus facing inside the cell, e.g., low-density lipoprotein receptor.

 

Type 2 membrane proteins have the N-terminal towards the cytosol and the C-terminal towards the exterior, e.g., transferrin receptor.

 

Type 3 membrane proteins are identical to type 1 but have a shorter N terminal, e.g., cytochrome P450 enzyme complexes.

 

Type 4 membrane proteins consist of 7 alpha helices traversing the membrane, e.g., glucose transporters and G-protein-coupled receptors.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. At the C-terminal: This is incorrect because the signaling sequence in type 2 membrane proteins is not located at the C-terminal.

 

Option C. At the N-terminal: This is incorrect as well. In type 2 membrane proteins, the N-terminal is facing the cytoplasm, but the signaling sequence itself is located inside the membrane.

 

Option D. Both inside the membrane and at C-terminal: This is incorrect because the signaling sequence is located specifically inside the membrane, not at the C-terminal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The signaling sequence in type 2 membrane proteins is located inside the membrane, crucial for the proper orientation and insertion of the protein.

questions.text: Match the following : (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1-B, 2-A, 3-C, 4-D
 

Explanation:

 

  1. Facial nerve - B. Taste from anterior two-thirds of the tongue: The facial nerve (CN VII) is responsible for carrying taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It also controls the muscles of facial expression.
  2. Spinal accessory nerve - A. Shrugging of the shoulder: The spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) innervates the trapezius muscle, which is responsible for actions such as shrugging the shoulder and scapula elevation. It also contributes to head rotation.
  3. Glossopharyngeal nerve - C. Taste from the posterior one-third of the tongue: The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) carries taste sensations from the posterior one-third of the tongue. It also plays a role in swallowing and provides sensory information from the throat and tonsils.
  4. Mandibular nerve - D. Chewing: The mandibular nerve (V3) is a branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) and is responsible for innervating the muscles of mastication (chewing), as well as providing sensory input to the lower jaw, teeth, and gums.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Is commonly associated with concomitant hypothyroidism
Characterised by at least four distinct episodes per year

questions.text: Rapid cycling in bipolar disorder is characterised by all of the following features except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Occurs more commonly in men

 

  • Rapid cycling in bipolar disorder is defined by having four or more distinct mood episodes (mania, hypomania, or depression) within a single year.
  • This condition is more commonly observed in females.
  • Several factors, including hypothyroidism and substance abuse, can contribute to the likelihood of rapid cycling.
  • Additionally, the use of antidepressants has been found to increase the risk of triggering rapid cycling episodes.
  • Mood stabilizer of choice - Valproate

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Is commonly associated with concomitant hypothyroidism: This statement is correct. Hypothyroidism is known to be associated with an increased risk of rapid cycling in bipolar disorder.

 

Option C. Characterised by at least four distinct episodes per year: This statement is correct. The definition of rapid cycling specifically includes the occurrence of four or more mood episodes in one calendar year.

 

Option D. Antidepressants increase the likelihood: This statement is correct. The use of antidepressants can indeed increase the likelihood of rapid cycling in individuals with bipolar disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rapid cycling in bipolar disorder is more commonly seen in females and is characterized by at least four distinct episodes per year.

questions.text: The rupture of penile urethra does not cause extravasation of blood into which of the following spaces? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Deep perineal pouch

 

Option B. Deep perineal pouch: This is a space situated superior to the perineal membrane and inferior to the pelvic diaphragm. It contains the membranous urethra, deep transverse perineal muscles, and parts of the external urethral sphincter. Extravasation of urine is possible in deep perineal pouch.

 

When there is a rupture of the penile urethra (often due to trauma, such as a straddle injury), the extravasation of urine and blood can occur into various anatomical spaces, depending on the location and nature of the injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial perineal pouch: This is a space located in the urogenital triangle of the perineum, bounded above by the perineal membrane and below by the perineal (Colles') fascia. The pouch contains the root of the penis (including the bulb of the penis) and the associated muscles. A rupture of the penile urethra can cause extravasation of urine and blood into this space.

 

Option C. Skin around penis. The skin around base of penis may get involved if the rupture is located in the bulbous part of urethra.

 

Option D. Skin around the scrotum: With a rupture of the penile urethra, especially if the rupture occurs in the bulbous part located within the superficial perineal pouch, the extravasated urine and blood can dissect through the fascial layers and present as swelling and bruising around the scrotum and base of the penis. This is often referred to as a "butterfly" pattern of bruising, as the extravasated fluid can spread anteriorly onto the anterior abdominal wall and laterally to the thighs but is typically limited superiorly by Scarpa's fascia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rupture of the penile urethra causes extravasation of blood into the superficial perineal pouch, scrotum, penis, and then up to the lower anterior abdominal wall.

 

The membranous layer of superficial fascia attaches to the ischiopubic rami and forms the lateral borders of the urogenital triangle. Thus, the urine does not extravasate to the thigh.

questions.text: Insulin independent absorption occurs in all except: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adipose

 

Glucose uptake in adipose tissue is insulin-dependent, primarily using GLUT4 transporters activated by insulin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RBC: Red Blood Cells utilize GLUT1 transporters for glucose absorption, which is insulin-independent and crucial for their energy needs.

 

Option C. Pancreas: While the pancreas plays a role in insulin production, its glucose absorption is not predominantly insulin-independent.

 

Option D. Brain: The brain absorbs glucose independently of insulin, using GLUT3 transporters, essential for its constant energy requirements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose uptake in adipose tissue is insulin-dependent, while RBCs, pancreas, and brain utilize insulin-independent mechanisms for glucose absorption.

questions.text: Which joint allows for the side-to-side movement of the head, enabling a person to look to the right and left?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Atlanto-axial

 

  • The movements at the atlanto-axial joint allow a person to look left and right.
  • The atlanto-axial joints consist of two lateral joints located on either side between the bottom of the atlas bone and the top of the axis bone, which are flat joints.
  • Additionally, there is a central joint between the dens (a protrusion from the axis bone) and the front arch and transverse ligament of the atlas, which is a pivot joint.
  • This central joint has two distinct synovial cavities - one in the front and one in the back.
  • Rotatory movements occur at all three joints and revolve around a vertical axis.
  • The dens acts as a pivot around which the atlas rotates (carrying the skull with it), allowing the head to rotate side to side.
  • The alar ligaments restrict movement. Atlanto-axial rotation has a normal range of about 40°.

 

Atlanto-Axial joint

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atlanto-occipital joint: This joint is formed between the first cervical vertebra (the atlas or C1) and the occipital bone of the skull. It primarily permits the "nodding" motion of the head, as in signaling "yes". This joint allows for flexion and extension of the head, but not significant rotation. It's the joint that lets you tilt your head upward or downward.

 

Option C. C2-C3 joint: This joint is between the second and third cervical vertebrae. While it does allow for some degree of rotation, it does not provide the primary rotational movement to look right or left. The range of motion at this joint is less compared to the atlanto-axial joint, and it's more involved in flexion, extension, and some lateral bending.

 

Option D. C3-C4 joint: This joint is between the third and fourth cervical vertebrae. Like the C2-C3 joint, the C3-C4 joint also provides some degree of rotation but not the primary movement. Its main movements are flexion, extension, and lateral bending of the neck. The lower down the cervical spine you go, the less rotational capacity there typically is at each subsequent joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atlanto-axial joint is formed between the first cervical vertebra (the atlas or C1) and the second cervical vertebra (the axis or C2). The dens or odontoid process, fits into the atlas, allowing for a pivot-like rotation. This is the joint responsible for allowing the rotation of the head from side to side, as in signaling "no" or looking right and left. It provides the majority of the rotational capability of the head.

questions.text:
Arrange in sequence the structures involved in the direct pathway: (INICET NOV 2022)

 

1. Striatum

2. Globus pallidus

3. Substantia nigra

4. Thalamus

5. Cortex
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 5,1,2,3,4

 

Explanation:

 

The correct sequence is as follows:

 

5. Cortex - provides the initial input to the basal ganglia.

 

1. Striatum - receives input from the cortex and is the first structure in the basal ganglia circuitry.

 

2. Globus pallidus - receives inhibitory input from the striatum and projects to the thalamus.

 

3. Substantia nigra - provides dopaminergic input to the striatum.

 

4. Thalamus - receives excitatory input from the globus pallidus and projects back to the cortex to complete the loop.

 

The basal ganglia needs the input from the cortex in order to act. The first and last component of the pathway is always the cerebral cortex. 


The complete pathway is Cortex/ Thalamus/ brain stem to stratum, then to globus pallidus & substantia nigra then to thalamus and then back to cortex.


Hence out of the available options 5,1,2,3,4 is the best suitable.

 

 

 

The putamen is located laterally and the internal capsule is located medially to the pallidum. The striatum and subthalamic nuclei send fibres to it. It is the primary basal ganglia output to the thalamus and superior colliculus. Each cerebral peduncle of the midbrain located deep to the crus cerebri contains the substantia nigra. Dopamine levels in the substantia nigra and striata are reduced in Parkinson's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of structures in the direct pathway of the basal ganglia starts with the cortex and follows through the striatum, globus pallidus, substantia nigra, and ends at the thalamus. This pathway is fundamental in processing motor signals, which is particularly relevant in understanding disorders like Parkinson’s disease.

choices.text: Calcium Channel Blocker action
Nitric oxide mediated vasodilation

questions.text: An elderly woman on treatment for migraine presents with chest pain. She has a previous history of ischemic heart disease. Which of the following mechanism of the prescribed drug for migraine might have caused this presentation? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 5-HT agonist

 

Chest pain in an elderly woman with a history of ischemic heart disease, who is on treatment for migraine, could potentially be linked to the mechanism of action of her migraine medication. Among the options given 5-HT agonists can cause this adverse effect. Triptans and ergotamine are a group of drugs that are used in acute attacks of migraine. They act on 5HT1B/1D receptors as agonist and cause vasoconstriction of the blood vessels. Therefore, they should be avoided in patients with coronary artery disease as they can precipitate myocardial infarction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5-HT Antagonist: Serotonin (5-HT) antagonists like cyproheptadine and methysergide etc are used for prophylaxis of migraine (not in treatment). These drugs are not commonly associated with causing chest pain or exacerbating ischemic heart disease.

 

Option C. Calcium Channel Blocker Action: While calcium channel blockers (CCBs) are used in migraine prophylaxis, they are generally heart-protective and used in the treatment of angina and hypertension due to their vasodilatory effects. It's unlikely that CCBs would cause chest pain.

 

Option D. Nitric Oxide Mediated Vasodilation: Nitric oxide donors (like nitrates) are used in the treatment of angina due to their vasodilatory effects. They are not typically used in migraine treatment, and their vasodilatory action would be more likely to relieve, rather than cause, ischemic chest pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5-HT Agonist includes medications like triptans (e.g., sumatriptan), which are commonly used in migraine treatment. Triptans are 5-HT1B/1D receptor agonists and can cause vasoconstriction of blood vessels. In patients with ischemic heart disease, this vasoconstriction can exacerbate angina (chest pain) or precipitate myocardial infarction, especially if the coronary arteries are already compromised.

choices.text: Adequate safety profile needs to be established
Cost to benefit has to be considered
Fixed dose combination of drugs is preferred over single drugs

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the selection of essential drugs? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Fixed dose combination of drugs is preferred over single drugs

 

The WHO has defined Essential Medicines (Drugs) as “those that satisfy the priority healthcare needs of the population. They are selected with due regard to public health relevance, evidence on efficacy and safety, and comparative cost effectiveness. Essential medicines are intended to be available within the context of functioning health systems at all times and in adequate amounts, in appropriate dosage forms, with assured quality and adequate information, and at a price the individual and the community can afford.”

 

This is generally false. While fixed-dose combinations (FDCs) can be beneficial in certain scenarios (like in the treatment of HIV/AIDS or tuberculosis), they are not universally preferred over single-drug formulations. The preference for FDCs or single drugs depends on several factors, including the therapeutic context, the risk of drug-drug interactions, patient adherence, and the potential for resistance development. Mostly, single drugs are preferred due to their flexibility in dosing and the ability to adjust individual components based on patient needs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adequate safety profile needs to be established: This is true. When selecting essential drugs, it's crucial that they have a well-established safety profile. Safety is a key consideration to ensure that the benefits of a drug outweigh its risks.

 

Option B. Cost to benefit has to be considered: This is also true. In the selection of essential drugs, the cost-effectiveness of a drug is an important factor. The aim is to provide the most effective treatment at the lowest possible cost.

 

Option D. Disease prevalence is considered: This is true. When selecting essential drugs, the prevalence of diseases in a population is an important consideration. Drugs to treat common and life-threatening diseases are typically prioritized.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The selection of essential drugs prioritizes factors like safety, cost-effectiveness, and disease prevalence. Fixed-dose combinations are not universally preferred over single drugs, as the choice depends on specific therapeutic needs and other considerations.

choices.text: The "ebb" phase is associated with a decline in body temperature and oxygen consumption
The "flow" phase occurs after resuscitation from a state of shock
The "ebb" phase is aimed at reducing posttraumatic energy depletion
The "ebb" phase leads to activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Cuthbertson's metabolic ebb and flow responses to trauma?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. The "ebb" phase leads to activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response

 

Explanation

 

The "flow" phase (not "ebb") leads to activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response.

 

Cuthbertson's ebb and flow response to trauma:

 

A short ebb phase characterized by hypometabolism occurs immediately after the injury and is characterized by a decrease in metabolic rate, oxygen consumption, body temperature, and enzymatic activity. The ebb phase is followed by a longer hypermetabolic flow phase marked by an increased catabolism, with a high oxygen consumption and an elevated resting energy expenditure rate.

 

The "flow" phase occurs after resuscitation from a state of shock, which leads to an increased metabolic turnover, activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The "ebb" phase is associated with a decline in body temperature and oxygen consumption: Correct, this describes the initial hypometabolic state following trauma.

 

Option B. The "flow" phase occurs after resuscitation from a state of shock: Correct, marking the transition to a hypermetabolic state.

 

Option C. The "ebb" phase is aimed at reducing posttraumatic energy depletion: Correct, as it focuses on conserving energy immediately after trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The statement that the "ebb" phase leads to activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response is false. These processes are characteristics of the "flow" phase, which occurs after the initial ebb phase and involves increased metabolic activity and systemic responses aimed at recovery and defense.

choices.text: C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers
A fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers
A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers
A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers

questions.text: A person after sleeping overnight with the arm under his head now experiences paresis but no numbness in the morning. Which of the following is the best explanation for it?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers

 

Explanation

 

In the above scenario, the patient has developed paresis (partial paralysis) but the pain sensation is intact (no numbness) suggests A fibers involvement as they carry motor, touch, and pressure sensations are most sensitive to pressure changes/compression.

 

A fibers are myelinated nerve fibers responsible for transmitting signals related to touch, pressure, and proprioception (the sense of one's body position). C fibers, on the other hand, are unmyelinated and transmit slower pain signals. While both types of fibers can be affected by pressure, A fibers are more vulnerable to damage from sustained pressure than C fibers, which are more resistant to compression.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers. - Incorrect. C fibers are unmyelinated and relatively more resistant to pressure compared to myelinated A fibers.

 

Option B. A fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers. - Not relevant to the scenario, as the issue is related to mechanical pressure, not oxygen deprivation.

 

Option D. A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers. - Also not relevant to the given scenario, focusing on hypoxia instead of the impact of mechanical pressure or compression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Relative susceptibility -

questions.text: The ossification center of the clavicle used to confirm bone age for legal consent to marriage is? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Sternal end

 

Explanation:

 

The sternal (medial) end of the clavicle is the ossification center used to confirm bone age for legal consent to marriage. This is a critical ossification center for age estimation in the late teens and early twenties. The secondary center at the medial end of the clavicle appears at around 18 years of age and fuses with the shaft by 21-22 years of age in males (slightly earlier in females).

 

In the context of legal consent to marriage, which typically requires individuals to be at least 18 years for females and 21 years for males in many jurisdictions, the fusion status of the medial end of the clavicle provides valuable evidence for age determination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acromial end (Incorrect) The acromial (lateral) end of the clavicle is not commonly used for age determination related to legal consent for marriage as it fuses earlier and doesn't provide relevant age information for the late teens to early twenties.

 

Option C. Shaft (Incorrect) The shaft (body) of the clavicle is the primary ossification center that appears very early (around 5-6 weeks of intrauterine life) and is the first bone to begin ossification. It doesn't provide useful information for age estimation in the context of marriage consent.

 

Option D. Tubercle (Incorrect) The tubercle of the clavicle doesn't have a separate ossification center that would be relevant for age determination in the context of legal consent for marriage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The medial (sternal) end of the clavicle is a key marker for age estimation between 18-22 years, making it highly valuable for legal age determination in marriage consent cases.

choices.text: Foreign body obstruction in the bronchus
When 02 and CO2 ratio is equal
The PO2 of alveolar air is 159 mmHg and PCO2 is 40 mmHg

questions.text: V/Q = infinity holds true in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Equal to dead space

 

Explanation

 

VA/Q= infinity suggests that Q is 0 which implies that there is no exchange of 02 & CO2, and no gaseous exchange occurs in dead space.

 

In quantitative terms, the ventilation-perfusion ratio is expressed as Va/Q. When Va (alveolar ventilation) is normal for a given alveolus and Q (blood flow) is also normal for the same alveolus, the ventilation-perfusion ratio (Va/Q) is also said to be normal.

 

This ratio explains the respiratory exchange when there is an imbalance between alveolar ventilation and alveolar blood flow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foreign body obstruction in the bronchus: Incorrect, as this condition would lead to an area with no ventilation (blocked by the foreign body) potentially resulting in a low V/Q ratio in the affected area rather than an infinite V/Q ratio.

 

Option C. When O2 and CO2 ratio is equal: Incorrect, as this does not directly relate to the ventilation-perfusion ratio concept. This option is more a reflection of gas exchange effectiveness rather than a description of V/Q mismatches.

 

Option D. The PO2 of alveolar air is 159 mmHg and PCO2 is 40 mmHg: Incorrect, these values are typical for normal alveolar air and do not indicate a V/Q mismatch situation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

VA /Q ratio is infinite in the following scenarios -

 

  1. Ventilation is normal but there is no perfusion.
  2. No gaseous exchange through the respiratory membranes of corresponding alveoli.
  3. The alveolar air equilibrates the humidified inspired air.
  4. Partial pressures of the 02 and CO, are 149 mmHg & 0 mm Hg respectively.

questions.text: A colonoscopy on an 80-year-old patient revealed brownish pigmented lesions, as shown below. He admitted to using laxatives on a regular basis. Which of the following laxatives is most likely to be the source of this problem? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Senna

 

The given image shows the colonoscopy finding of melanosis coli.

 

The use of stimulant purgatives like Senna , Cascara Sagrada and Bisacodyl can lead to the development of melanosis coli. Also they should not be used for more than 10 days due to the risk of developing atonic colon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bran: Bran is a bulk-forming laxative that increases stool bulk and promotes regular bowel movements. It does not cause melanosis coli.

 

Option B. Psyllium: Psyllium is another bulk-forming laxative that absorbs water into the stool, making it easier to pass. It does not lead to melanosis coli.

 

Option D. Methylcellulose: Methylcellulose is a bulk-forming fiber laxative that works by absorbing water and increasing stool bulk. It is not associated with melanosis coli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic use of stimulant laxatives like Senna can lead to melanosis coli, characterized by brownish-black pigmentation of the colonic mucosa seen on colonoscopy.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is an inhibitor of ATP binding cassette efflux pumps? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Verapamil

 

Verapamil is known to inhibit the activity of ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporters, such as P-glycoprotein, which is one of the most well-studied drug efflux transporters. By inhibiting P-glycoprotein, verapamil can increase the intracellular concentration of various drugs, which is why it is sometimes used as a pharmacokinetic enhancer to improve drug absorption and decrease drug clearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tacrolimus: Tacrolimus is an immunosuppressant drug used mainly after allogeneic organ transplant to reduce the activity of the patient's immune system and lower the risk of organ rejection. It is not an inhibitor of the ATP-binding cassette efflux transporters.

 

Option B. Nifedipine: Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker used primarily to treat hypertension and angina pectoris. It is not known to inhibit ABC efflux transporters.

 

Option C. Diltiazem: Diltiazem, like verapamil, is a calcium channel blocker, but it is not as potent as verapamil in inhibiting P-glycoprotein. However, it does have some effect on drug efflux transporters, but to a lesser extent compared to verapamil.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Verapamil is a known inhibitor of ATP-binding cassette transporters, particularly P-glycoprotein, and can be used to enhance the pharmacokinetics of various drugs by increasing their intracellular concentrations.

questions.text:
Erythropoietin is produced by: (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. Kidney
  2. Liver
  3. Spleen
  4. Lung
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 2

 

Explanation:

 

Erythropoietin is a hormone primarily produced by the kidneys and to a lesser extent by the liver. In a healthy individual, the majority of erythropoietin (approximately 90%) is produced by the kidney, specifically by peritubular interstitial fibroblasts. These cells respond to hypoxia (low oxygen levels) by increasing the production of erythropoietin, which then stimulates the bone marrow to produce more red blood cells. The liver also contributes to erythropoietin production, particularly through sinusoidal cells, although it accounts for only about 10% of the hormone's production under normal conditions.

 

In certain pathological conditions, such as in some types of anemia (e.g., thalassemia major), the spleen may take on a role in erythropoietin production to compensate for the body's increased need for red blood cells. However, this is not the case in healthy individuals, which is why the spleen and other organs like the lung are not considered significant sources of erythropoietin under normal physiological conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

3 and 4: While the spleen can contribute in pathological states, it is not a primary source under normal conditions, and the lung does not contribute to erythropoietin production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythropoietin is primarily produced by the kidneys, with the liver contributing to a lesser extent. Understanding the primary and secondary sources of erythropoietin is crucial, particularly in the context of conditions affecting red blood cell production.

questions.text:
What is/are correct statement(s) regarding skeletal muscle? (INICET May 2023)

 

  1. Extracellular calcium entry is important in the skeletal muscle contraction.
  2. Calcium is mainly released from mitochondria.
  3. Calcium is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
  4. Voltage-gated calcium channel on sarcolemma has no role in excitation-contraction coupling.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Only 3

 

The accurate fact concerning skeletal muscle is that the release of calcium occurs from the sarcoplasmic reticulum only.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Extracellular calcium plays a significant role in sustaining cardiac muscle contraction , not in skeletal muscle.

 

2. The sarcoplasmic reticulum is filled with high concentrations of calcium ions stored in its vesicular tubules. Upon the occurrence of an action potential in the neighboring T tubule, these calcium ions are discharged from each vesicle.

 

4. Activation of  voltage-gated calcium channel is essential in excitation-contraction coupling, i.e. it a has important role. Activation of receptor results in the initiation of calcium release from RyR channels, leading to the liberation of calcium ions from the sarcoplasm surrounding the myofibrils, consequently triggering muscle contraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum is essential for skeletal muscle contraction.

questions.text: A patient was started on Amitryptiline and he was found to be unconscious. Which of the following doesn’t suggest TCA toxicity ?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypothermia

 

TCA toxicity typically presents with hyperthermia due to anticholinergic effects, not hypothermia.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arrhythmias: Arrhythmias are a hallmark of TCA toxicity, reflecting its impact on cardiac conductivity.

 

Option B. Confusion: Confusion or altered sensorium is common due to the central nervous system effects of TCAs.

 

Option D. Pupillary dilatation: Pupillary dilatation results from the anticholinergic properties of TCAs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In cases of TCA toxicity, we see symptoms like arrhythmias, confusion, and pupillary dilatation due to its anticholinergic and cardiotoxic properties. Hypothermia is not typically associated with TCA overdose.

questions.text: In this case, a young boy is exhibiting symptoms of reduced mood, decreased energy, and diminished engagement with his environment. He has refrained from eating for the past week and his thoughts include phrases like "I have lost my mind. I am deceased. How can I consume food?". What is the specific delusion in this scenario? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nihilistic delusion

 

Nihilistic delusion (delusion of negation, Cotard syndrome): Patients may deny the existence of their body, their mind, or the world in general. For example, a patient with severe depression claimed that all his internal organs have rotted.

 

Here, the best answer is Nihilistic delusion rather than Cotard syndrome because the question has specifically asked the type of delusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypochondriacal delusion: Hypochondriacal delusion is an illness anxiety disorder. It is characterized by a preoccupation with having or acquiring a serious physical illness. The preoccupation persists despite normal investigations and medical reassurances.

 

Option D. Bizarre delusion: Scientifically impossible and culturally implausible (un-understandable). For example, a patient claimed that aliens stole his heart and lungs, and now he is living without those organs.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man weighing 70 kg had a sodium level of 120 mEq, calculate sodium deficit? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 840 mEq

 

Explanation

 

The sodium deficit in the given scenario is 840 mEq.

 

Formula for calculating sodium deficit = 0.6 × body weight x (target plasma sodium concentration - starting plasma sodium concentration).

 

Substituting values as per the question,

 

Sodium deficit = 0.6 x 70 × (140 - 120) = 840 mEq.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Correcting sodium levels must be done cautiously, especially in cases of hyponatremia, to prevent complications like osmotic demyelination syndrome. Rapid changes in serum sodium can be dangerous, and adjustments should generally be made slowly, according to specific clinical guidelines.

questions.text: Which joint is not formed by the bone shown in the image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Synchondrosis

 

The image shows a thoracic vertebra, identifiable by its long spinous process, body, and superior and inferior articular facets. Thoracic vertebrae participate in forming several types of joints but do not form synchondroses. A synchondrosis is a primary cartilaginous joint where bones are joined by hyaline cartilage, which is not present in the thoracic vertebra.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syndesmosis: Incorrect. Syndesmosis joints are formed where two bones are connected by a ligament. An example related to the vertebrae would be the interspinous ligament connecting adjacent spinous processes.

 

Option C. Plane joint: Incorrect. Plane joints are formed by thoracic vertebrae, such as the costovertebral and costotransverse joints, where the ribs articulate with the thoracic vertebrae.

 

Option D. Symphysis: Incorrect. Symphysis joints are formed between the vertebral bodies of adjacent thoracic vertebrae via the intervertebral discs, which are composed of fibrocartilage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thoracic vertebrae do not form synchondrosis (primary cartilaginous) joints; they are involved in forming plane joints, syndesmosis, and symphysis joints.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drug is associated with increased risk of urinary tract infections? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dapagliflozin

 

Dapagliflozin is a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor. SGLT2 inhibitors work by promoting the excretion of glucose through the urine. This increased urinary glucose can create an environment that promotes the growth of bacteria, thereby increasing the risk of urinary tract infections. This class of drugs is well known for its association with UTIs and genital infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pioglitazone: Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that improves insulin sensitivity. It is not associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections. Common side effects include weight gain, edema, and an increased risk of heart failure.

 

Option C. Sitagliptin: Sitagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor. It works by increasing incretin levels, which in turn increase insulin secretion and decrease glucagon secretion. Sitagliptin is not commonly associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections.

 

Option D. Metformin: Metformin is a biguanide that decreases hepatic glucose production and improves insulin sensitivity. It is not associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections. Common side effects of metformin include gastrointestinal disturbances such as diarrhea and abdominal discomfort.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, dapagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections due to its mechanism of increasing glucose excretion in the urine. This patient’s recurrent UTIs could be related to her use of dapagliflozin.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about exanthema subitum is incorrect? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Associated with Slapped Cheek Appearance

 

Explanation:

  • Exanthema subitum, also called Sixth Disease or Roseola infantum, is caused by Human Herpes Virus-6 (HHV-6). 
  • The disease is characterized by abrupt onset of high-grade fever, followed by appearance of the rash after the fever subsides. 
  • The rash resembles measles but is not described as having a "slapped cheek appearance." Nagayama spots are associated with this condition, but not a slapped cheek appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Known as Sixth Disease - This is correct. 

 

  • Exanthema subitum is indeed known as the Sixth Disease in the classification of childhood exanthems.

 

Option B. Known as Roseola - This is correct. 

 

  • HHV-6 causes "roseola infantum" where "roseola" means rose-like and "infantum" refers to its common occurrence in infants.

 

Option C. Caused by Herpes Virus - This is correct. 

 

  • Exanthema subitum is caused by Human Herpes Virus-6 (HHV-6), which is a member of the herpesvirus family.

 

Option D. Associated with Slapped Cheek Appearance - This is incorrect. 

 

  • The "slapped cheek appearance" is characteristic of Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease) caused by Parvovirus B19, not exanthema subitum. 

 

 

  • Parvovirus B19 infection causes a maculopapular rash that evolves into a reticulated lacy exanthem

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Exanthema subitum (Sixth Disease/Roseola infantum) is caused by HHV-6, characterized by abrupt high fever followed by a rash after fever subsides, while the "slapped cheek appearance" is characteristic of Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease) caused by Parvovirus B19.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is attached to the area marked green in the image below? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Opponens pollicis

 

Explanation:

 

The palmar aspect of the first metacarpal is the area marked in the image. At this location, the opponens pollicis muscle inserts.

 

  • Opponens pollicis:
  • Origin: Crest of the trapezium and flexor retinaculum
  • Insertion: Whole length of the lateral border and adjoining lateral half of the palmar aspect of the first metacarpal.
  • Action: Flexes the metacarpal bone of the thumb.

 

The image below shows various intrinsic muscles of the hand.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abductor Pollicis Longus: Abductor pollicis longus is not directly attached to the first metacarpal. It originates from the posterior surface of the ulna and radius and inserts into the base of the first metacarpal bone. Its primary action is to abduct the thumb away from the palm.

 

Option B. Palmar Interossei: The palmar interossei muscles are located between the metacarpal bones in the palm of the hand. They are responsible for adducting the fingers toward the midline of the hand. They are not directly attached to the first metacarpal.

 

Option D. Flexor Pollicis Brevis: The flexor pollicis brevis muscle has two heads: the superficial head and the deep head. The superficial head originates from the flexor retinaculum, while the deep head originates from the trapezoid and capitate bones.

  • Both heads of the flexor pollicis brevis insert into the base of the first metacarpal bone.
  • The main action of the flexor pollicis brevis is to flex the thumb at the metacarpophalangeal joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The opponens pollicis muscle originates from the flexor retinaculum and the Crest of the trapezium bone. It inserts into the first metacarpal bone.
  • The primary action of the opponens pollicis is to oppose the thumb, allowing for the grasping and pinching movements of the thumb.

choices.text: Repeated administration of ephedrine decreases its effect on blood pressure
High dose of acetylcholine after pretreatment with atropine produces increase in blood pressure and heart rate
A patient pre-treated with phentolamine develops severe hypotension on administration of adrenaline
Increase in blood pressure is produced by intravenous propranolol

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the phenomenon of vasomotor reversal of Dale? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A patient pre-treated with phentolamine develops severe hypotension on administration of adrenaline

 

Vasomotor Reversal of Dale:

 

Adrenaline stimulates both α1 and β2 receptors. The α1 receptors have very strong vasoconstrictor property whereas the β2 receptors are very sensitive receptors and they cause vasodilation. Since the α1 receptors are stronger, on administration of adrenaline, they are stimulated leading to vasoconstriction. After some time, metabolism takes place and only β2 is stimulated which causes low blood pressure. This phase does not also last for a long time as metabolism happens and brings back the blood pressure to the normal level. This is the biphasic response of adrenaline (two phases in which BP increases in the first phase and decreases in the second).

 

Phentolamine is a non-selective alpha blocker. So if adrenaline is administered along with it , then the alpha receptor stimulation will not happen , and there will be only stimulation of the β2 receptors leading to vasodilation and severe hypotension. This phenomenon of a patient pretreated with phentolamine developing severe hypotension on the administration of adrenaline is known as the vasomotor reversal of Dale.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeated administration of ephedrine decreases its effect on blood pressure: This describes tachyphylaxis, which is a rapid decrease in response to a drug after repeated doses, not vasomotor reversal of Dale.

 

Option B. High dose of acetylcholine after pretreatment with atropine produces an increase in blood pressure and heart rate: This describes the pharmacological effects of acetylcholine and atropine but is unrelated to vasomotor reversal of Dale.

 

Option D. Increase in blood pressure is produced by intravenous propranolol: Propranolol is a non-selective beta blocker that usually causes a decrease in blood pressure by blocking β1 and β2 receptors, leading to reduced cardiac output and vasodilation. This statement is incorrect and unrelated to vasomotor reversal of Dale.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The phenomenon of vasomotor reversal of Dale occurs when a patient pre-treated with an alpha blocker like phentolamine experiences severe hypotension upon administration of adrenaline due to the unopposed stimulation of β2 receptors, leading to vasodilation instead of the usual vasoconstriction and pressor effect.

questions.text: All of the following are types of polysaccharide vaccines except: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Hepatitis B

 

Hepatitis B is not a polysaccharide vaccine. It is a recombinant type of subunit vaccine, which means it is made using genetic engineering techniques to produce the surface antigens of the Hepatitis B virus

 

Other Options:

 

Polysaccharide vaccines are designed to elicit an immune response specifically against the polysaccharides found on the surface of certain bacterial capsules. These vaccines include:

 

Option A. Haemophilus influenzae B (Hib) vaccine: Targets the polysaccharides on the surface of Haemophilus influenzae type B.

 

Option B. Pneumococcal vaccine: Targets the polysaccharides on the surface of Streptococcus pneumoniae.

 

Option D. Meningococcal vaccine: Targets the polysaccharides on the surface of Neisseria meningitidis.

 

These vaccines may also be available as glycoconjugate vaccines, which are designed to improve immunogenicity, especially in younger populations. However, the vaccine for Salmonella Typhimurium (Typhim VI) is available only in a polysaccharide form.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B is a recombinant subunit vaccine, not a polysaccharide vaccine. Polysaccharide vaccines include those for pneumococcus, meningococcus, and Haemophilus influenzae type B.

 

Note - Polysaccharide vaccines work by stimulating the immune system to produce antibodies specifically against the polysaccharide components of the bacterial capsule. These polysaccharides are unique to particular strains or serotypes of bacteria, making the vaccine effective in targeting those specific types.

 

Limitations of Polysaccharide vaccines: serotype-specific and do not facilitate herd immunity due to their lack of a robust T-cell response.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT involved in renal auto-regulation?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Renal sympathetic system fires

 

Renal autoregulation is important to maintain the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Blood flow to kidneys remains normal even when the mean arterial blood pressure very widely between 60 mm Hg and 180 mm Hg. This helps to maintain normal GFR.

The sympathetic nervous system can also influence renal blood flow, but its role is primarily to modulate GFR in response to systemic conditions rather than as part of the intrinsic autoregulatory mechanisms. Therefore, renal sympathetic system firing is not considered a key component of renal autoregulation.

 

Two mechanisms are involved in renal autoregulation:

 

  1. Myogenic response - mechanism that contributes to the maintenance of a relatively constant renal blood flow and GFR
  2. Tubuloglomerular feedback via macula densa. Renin-angiotensin system also plays a role.

 

 

 

 

Macula densa feedback mechanism for autoregulation of glomerular hydrostatic pressure and glomerular filtration rate (GFR) during decreased renal arterial pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tubuloglomerular feedback: Incorrect. Tubuloglomerular feedback is a key component of renal autoregulation.

 

Option B. Myogenic reflex: Incorrect. The myogenic reflex is a crucial mechanism in renal autoregulation.The myogenic reflex helps regulate GFR by directly responding to changes in blood pressure (BP) within the afferent arteriole, which supplies blood to the glomerulus. When BP  increases, the afferent arteriole smooth muscle stretches, triggering a contraction (vasoconstriction) that reduces blood flow into the glomerulus, thus decreasing GFR.

 

Option C. Renin-angiotensin system: Incorrect. The renin-angiotensin system supports renal autoregulation, particularly in adjusting the efferent arteriolar resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal autoregulation primarily involves the myogenic response and tubuloglomerular feedback mechanisms to maintain stable GFR. The renal sympathetic system, while involved in renal blood flow regulation, is not part of intrinsic autoregulation mechanisms.

questions.text: A patient after a road traffic accident presents to the emergency room with difficulty in swallowing and slurred speech. Investigations reveal fractures in the occipitotemporal region. Which of the following areas should be tested in order to find the nerve which is involved? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2

 

Explanation:

 

The occipitotemporal fracture in the clinical scenario is suggestive of involvement of the 9th and 10th cranial nerves, which are tested by pressing on the uvula, which is indicated as 2 in the image.

 

The jugular foramen is located between the lower border of the petrous part of the temporal bone and the condylar part of the occipital bone. As the investigations reveal fractures in the occipitotemporal region, along with the history of difficulty in swallowing and slurred speech, are suggestive of injury to the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerve passing through the jugular foramen.

 

Unilateral lesions of IX and X cranial nerves are commonly caused by skull-base fractures, strokes, or tumors.

 

Glossopharyngeal and Vagus nerve examination include:

 

  • Observing the position and symmetry of the palate and uvula(marked as 2 in the given image) at rest and with phonation ("aah").
  • The pharyngeal (gag") reflex is evaluated by stimulating the posterior pharyngeal wall on each side with a sterile, blunt object (e.g., tongue blade)

 

Individuals who have a proximal unilateral vagus nerve lesion report having trouble swallowing. On the affected side, the soft palate muscles will be weak. When the patient is asked to utter "aah," for example, an attempt to elevate the soft palate voluntarily will demonstrate a deficit in that side's ability to do so. Due to the palatal muscles' unopposed action on that side, there will also be a deviation of the uvula to the typical side along with this.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. 1: This area does not relate to the glossopharyngeal or vagus nerves, which are crucial in the described symptoms.

 

Option. C. 3: This area is likely distant from the jugular foramen where nerves IX and X pass, thus not directly involved with the symptoms presented.

 

Option. D. 4: This lower section of the brain and skull does not typically involve the pathways or exit points of the cranial nerves implicated in swallowing and speech functions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of occipitotemporal fractures with symptoms of difficulty in swallowing and slurred speech, it is critical to assess the function of the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves, as these are commonly affected by such injuries. Testing should focus on the functionality of the palate and uvula where these nerves can be clinically evaluated.

choices.text: Mode is affected by extreme values
Mean is affected by extreme values
Median is calculated by overall observations
Mode can be used as a qualitative data descriptor

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false for descriptors of central tendency? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Mode is affected by extreme values

 

  • Extreme values in a given dataset do not influence the mode.
  • Mode is the most frequent or most commonly occurring value in a distribution.
  • It is uninfluenced by extreme values and can be used to describe qualitative data

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mean is affected by extreme values: This is true. Extreme values (outliers) can significantly affect the mean, making it an unreliable measure of central tendency in skewed distributions.

 

Option C. Median is calculated by overall observations: This is true. The median is determined by arranging all observations in order and finding the middle value, or the average of the two middle values if the number of observations is even.

 

Option D. Mode can be used as a qualitative data descriptor: This is true. The mode is applicable to qualitative data as it represents the most frequently occurring category or value.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The mode is not affected by extreme values and can be used to describe qualitative data.
  • In contrast, the mean is affected by extreme values, and the median is a robust measure of central tendency that is calculated using overall observations.

questions.text: Which of the following physiological adaptations is generally not observed at high altitudes? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Respiratory acidosis

 

The physiological adaptation that does not happen at high altitudes is respiratory acidosis. Respiratory alkalosis is the physiological adaptation seen at high altitudes due to hyperventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary vasoconstriction: Correct, as it is a physiological response to low oxygen levels to improve gas exchange.

 

Option B. Polycythemia: Correct, as it increases the blood's oxygen-carrying capacity.

 

Option D. Hypoxia: Correct, as it is the primary condition caused by low oxygen levels at high altitudes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The principal means by which acclimatization to high altitude comes about are

 

  1. A great increase in pulmonary ventilation - increase in pulmonary ventilation on rising to a high altitude blows off large quantities of carbon dioxide, reducing the Pco2 and increasing the ph of the body fluids.
  2. Increased numbers of red blood cells,
  3. Increased diffusing capacity of the lungs,
  4. Increased vascularity of the peripheral tissues
  5. Increased ability of the tissue cells to use oxygen despite low Po2.
  6. Cellular Acclimatization - cell mitochondria and cellular oxidative enzyme systems are slightly more plentiful than in sea-level inhabitants

questions.text: Identify the prominent nerve pointed in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Great auricular nerve

 

The thickened nerve marked with the arrow in the above image is the great auricular nerve.

 

 

Great auricular nerve:

 

  • The great auricular nerve is the cervical plexus's largest ascending branch, arising from the anterior rami of spinal nerves C2 and C3.
  • The nerve emerges just behind the sternocleidomastoid muscle's middle portion, curves around its posterior border, and emerges on the muscle's anterior surface.
  • The great auricular nerve perforates the deep cervical fascia and ascends along the external jugular vein, passing under the platysma muscle.
  • The great auricular nerve divides into terminal branches as it approaches the parotid gland.

 

Clinical considerations:

 

  • ﻿﻿Leprosy - Nerve thickening is present. The nerve is palpable over the upper part of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. (As seen in the above image)
  • ﻿﻿Frey's syndrome - An aberrant connection between the auriculotemporal nerve and great auricular nerve causes gustatory sweating.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lesser Occipital Nerve: The lesser occipital nerve is another branch of the cervical plexus, arising from the second cervical spinal nerve (C2). It provides sensory innervation to the skin over the posterior part of the scalp.

 

Option C. Facial Nerve: The facial nerve, also known as the seventh cranial nerve (CN VII), is a mixed nerve responsible for controlling the muscles of facial expression. It also carries taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It does not primarily provide sensory innervation to the skin.

 

Option D. Auriculotemporal Nerve: The auriculotemporal nerve is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3). It supplies sensory innervation to the external ear and the skin of the temple region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The great auricular nerve is a branch of the cervical plexus, specifically originating from the second and third cervical spinal nerves (C2-C3). It provides sensory innervation to the skin over the parotid gland, the external ear, and the angle of the mandible.

questions.text: The anteroposterior diameter of the skull is smallest in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: C. Brachycephaly

 

Explanation:

 

Brachycephaly (short-headed) is characterized by a skull that has a short anteroposterior diameter compared to its width. This is reflected in the cephalic index formula:

Cephalic Index = (Maximum transverse breadth of skull / Maximum anteroposterior length of skull) × 100

 

Brachycephalic skulls have a cephalic index of 80-85 and are found in Mongoloids. This high index value indicates that the width is large relative to a shorter anteroposterior length.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dolichocephaly (Incorrect) Dolichocephalic (long-headed) skulls have a cephalic index of 70-75. This indicates a longer anteroposterior diameter relative to width, not shorter.

 

Option B. Mesocephaly (Incorrect) Mesaticephalic (medium-headed) skulls have a cephalic index of 75-80. This represents an intermediate anteroposterior diameter.

 

Option D. Trigonocephaly (Incorrect) Trigonocephaly refers to a condition where the skull has a triangular appearance when viewed from above due to premature fusion of the metopic suture. It's not directly classified in the cephalic index system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cephalic index measures the ratio between skull width and length - the higher the index (as in brachycephaly), the shorter the anteroposterior diameter relative to width.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy was brought to the casualty with seizures. The pediatrician tries to do CSF sampling. What are the structures punctured by the pediatrician while piercing through the marked structure? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Scalp, dura, arachnoid

 

Explanation:

 

The arrow in the illustration, which displays a baby's skull, is pointing in the direction of the anterior fontanelle. Ventricular tapping is the term used to describe the process of removing CSF from the anterior fontanelle. The various structures pierced are the scalp, dura, and arachnoid.

 

Fontanelle tap/ Percutaneous ventricular puncture:

 

Infants who need urgent ventricular decompression and have an open anterior fontanelle and no access to a VP shunt undergo a fontanelle tap or percutaneous ventricular puncture. A butterfly needle is used to immediately puncture the infant's open fontanelle and enter the lateral ventricle in order to obtain CS samples, alleviate pressure, or insert a drain or catheter.

 

Procedure: A 25-gauge butterfly needle is inserted through the anterolateral aspect of the anterior fontanelle (away from the midline, avoiding the superior sagittal sinus).

 

When performing a fontanelle tap, the following layers are pierced:

 

  • Scalp: This includes the skin and the underlying connective tissue of the scalp.
  • Membranous fontanelle: The actual fontanelle is a soft spot on a baby's head where the bones of the skull have not yet fused together. It's a membranous gap between the cranial bones.
  • Dura mater: The tough outermost membrane of the three layers of the meninges that surround the brain and spinal cord.
  • Arachnoid mater: A thin, wispy layer that lies underneath the dura mater.
  • Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF): Once through the arachanoid mater, the needle enters the subarachnoid space where the CSF is located.

 

Note: The fontanelle tap bypasses the bony skull, which is why it's an accessible route in neonates and infants for procedures that require access to the CSF. However, as the child grows, these fontanelles close, and the method is no longer viable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fontanelle tap is a critical emergency procedure used in infants for CSF sampling or pressure relief from the ventricles, exploiting the unossified sections of the skull for direct access to the CSF. This procedure is unique to neonates and young infants where the fontanelle is present and typically involves piercing the scalp, dura, and arachnoid layers.

choices.text: MR SC and Oral Vitamin A at 8 months
MR IM and Oral Vitamin A at 8 months
MR SC and Oral Vitamin A at 9 months
MR IM and Oral Vitamin A at 9 months

questions.text: What is the schedule and route of administration of MR vaccine: [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) MR SC and Oral Vitamin A at 9 months

 

Option C : MR Sc and Oral Vitamin A at 9 months:

 

Explanation

 

This option is correct as per the National Immunization Schedule. The MR vaccine is given subcutaneously at 9 completed months along with the first dose of Vitamin A, aligning with the guidelines for both treatments.

 

Vitamin A Supplementation schedule

 

 

In total – 9 doses – 17 Lacs IU

 

Measles vaccine schedule

 

 

Educational objective :

 

The MR vaccine should be administered subcutaneously at 9 completed months, and the first dose of Vitamin A should be given concurrently. This regimen helps to ensure optimal immune response and nutritional support, which is crucial for preventing measles, rubella, and vitamin A deficiency-related health issues.

choices.text: Area under the curve

questions.text: The extent of drug absorption in plasma concentration vs time graph is represented by:(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Area under the curve

 

Area under the curve (AUC) is a measure of the total drug exposure in the bloodstream over time. It reflects the total amount of drug absorbed and is often used to assess the overall bioavailability of a drug. AUC is crucial for determining the efficacy and safety of a medication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tmax (Time to Maximum Concentration): Tmax represents the time it takes for a drug to reach its maximum concentration (Cmax) in the bloodstream. It tells about rate of drug absorption.

 

Option C. Cmax (Maximum Concentration): Cmax represents the highest concentration of a drug in the bloodstream after administration. This parameter is important because it indicates the peak therapeutic effect and helps assess the risk of side effects associated with high drug concentrations.

 

Option D. t1/2 (Half-Life): t1/2 is the time it takes for half of the drug to be eliminated from the bloodstream. It is not directly related to drug absorption but is essential in understanding how long a drug remains in the body and how often it needs to be administered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Area Under the Curve (AUC) in a plasma concentration vs. time graph represents the extent of drug absorption, reflecting the total drug exposure over time and the overall bioavailability of the drug.

choices.text: It most commonly affects ages 35-45 years
Type 1 is common in both sexes
Attempt to commit suicide is seen around 15% of people

questions.text: Which of the following is false about bipolar disorder? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It most commonly affects ages 35-45 years

 

Bipolar disorder, historically called manic-depressive illness, often begins in late adolescence or early adulthood. While it can start in childhood or later in life, this is less common.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Type 1 is common in both sexes: True. Bipolar I disorder has no gender bias and affects men and women equally.

 

Option C. Prevalence in the general population is 1-2%: True. Bipolar disorder affects about 1-2% of the global population.

 

Option D. Attempt to commit suicide is seen in around 15% of people: True. People with bipolar disorder have a high suicide risk, and approximately 15% may end up taking their own life.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bipolar disorder typically presents in late adolescence or early adulthood. It is characterized by episodes of mania and depression, affects both sexes equally, has a prevalence of 1-2% in the general population, and carries a significant risk of suicide.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 376.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿C is more potent than A
﻿﻿﻿B is more potent than A

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the dose-response curve shown in the image below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) B is competitive antagonist

 

This questions tests the knowledge regarding two different things about dose response curve:

 

a. Potency and Efficacy: Remember, to take HELP whenever in doubt. It means Height of the curve tells about Efficacy (higher the curve, the more efficacious the drug is) and Left sidedness of the curve tells about Potency (Drugs with curves on left side are more potent than drugs with curve on right side)

 

b. Type of Inhibition: If the curve shifts parallelly to right, the drug is a competitive inhibitor, if it shifts down, the drug is a non-competitive inhibitor.

 

What is given in graph: 

 

  • The DRC of drug B has shifted to the right of the DRC of drug A , although the height of the two curves is the same. On the other hand, Drug C has shifted the curve down.
  • Further height of curve in Drug A and B is same but more than Drug C.
  • Curve of Drug A is on most left followed by Drug C and then Drug B.

 

Inferences:

 

Therefore, the following inferences can be drawn from the given image:

 

  • The efficacy of Drug A = Drug B > Drug C
  • The Potency of Drug A > Drug C > Drug B
  • Drug B is a competitive inhibitor of Drug A
  • Drug C is a non-competitive inhibitor of Drug A

 

Educational Objective:

 

Efficacy: The height of the curve represents the efficacy of the drug. The higher the curve, the more efficacious the drug.

 

Potency: The position of the curve along the x-axis (left or right) indicates the potency. Drugs with curves on the left side are more potent than those on the right side.

 

Type of Inhibition

 

  • Competitive Inhibition: A competitive inhibitor will shift the dose-response curve to the right without changing the maximum effect (efficacy). This indicates that higher concentrations of the agonist can overcome the inhibition.
  • Non-Competitive Inhibition: A non-competitive inhibitor will reduce the maximum effect (efficacy) of the agonist, causing a downward shift in the dose-response curve.

questions.text: An 18-month-old child with ambiguous genitalia presented to the hospital, his BP is 88/68 mm Hg, Serum K+ is 6 mEq/L, serum sodium is 120 mEq/L. Patient was started on intravenous fluids. What additional specific therapy will you add?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hydrocortisone

 

The presentation of an 18-month-old child with ambiguous genitalia, hypertension (BP is 88/68 mm Hg, which is low for this age), hyperkalemia (serum K of 6 mEq/L), and hyponatremia (serum sodium of 120 mEq/L) is suggestive of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), most likely due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. This is a common form of CAH and can lead to a decrease in cortisol and aldosterone production, with an accompanying increase in adrenal androgens.

 

Given this clinical picture, the specific therapy to be added would include:

 

  1. Glucocorticoid Replacement: This is critical to suppress the overproduction of adrenal androgens. Hydrocortisone is commonly used, especially in pediatric patients, due to its short duration of action and lower impact on growth.

  2. Mineralocorticoid Replacement: Fludrocortisone is usually added to manage the aldosterone deficiency, which is contributing to the hyperkalemia and hyponatremia.

  3. Sodium Chloride Supplements: In some cases, especially in infants and young children, additional sodium chloride supplements may be necessary to manage hyponatremia.

  4. Monitoring and Adjustment: Regular monitoring of electrolytes, blood pressure, and growth is necessary to adjust therapy accordingly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Potassium Binding Resins: While these can be used to treat hyperkalemia, they do not address the underlying cause of the electrolyte imbalance in this scenario, which is likely due to aldosterone deficiency. Therefore, it would not be the first choice.

 

Option C. Digoxin: This is used primarily for heart failure and certain arrhythmias, not for the conditions described in this scenario.

 

Option D. Calcium Gluconate: This is used in the acute management of severe hyperkalemia to stabilize cardiac membranes. While it might be used in an emergency setting for life-threatening hyperkalemia, it does not address the underlying cause in this case and is not a long-term management strategy.

 

Therefore, the most appropriate addition to this patient's treatment regimen would be Hydrocortisone (option a), as it addresses the underlying cause of the symptoms in CAH. Additionally, monitoring and adjusting mineralocorticoid therapy (like fludrocortisone) would be important in the long-term management, especially given the electrolyte imbalances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most appropriate addition to this patient's treatment regimen would be Hydrocortisone, as it addresses the underlying cause of the symptoms in CAH. Additionally, monitoring and adjusting mineralocorticoid therapy (like fludrocortisone) would be important in the long-term management, especially given the electrolyte imbalances.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/314

choices.text: Safety in pregnancy
Dose adjustment in renal failure
Cost ratio from cheap to expensive
As per safety or therapeutic index

questions.text: Category A, B, C, D, X in drug classification is indicative of which of the following?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Safety in pregnancy

 

The categories A, B, C, D, and X are used to classify drugs based on their safety during pregnancy. This classification helps in determining the potential risk of medications to the fetus when taken during pregnancy.

 

Pregnancy drug category, which are indicative of their safety are as follows:

 

Category A > B > C > D > X

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dose adjustment in renal failure: Drug classifications for dose adjustments in renal failure typically involve guidelines based on the drug's pharmacokinetics and renal clearance. These guidelines are not categorized as A, B, C, D, X.

 

Option C. Cost ratio from cheap to expensive: Drug classifications based on cost are not typically denoted by the categories A, B, C, D, X. Cost-related classifications might be discussed in economic terms or based on generic versus brand name distinctions.

 

Option D. As per safety or therapeutic index: The therapeutic index of a drug, which measures its safety margin, is not categorized using the A, B, C, D, X system. The therapeutic index is a ratio comparing the toxic dose to the therapeutic dose, but it is not classified in this alphabetical manner.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classification of drugs into categories A, B, C, D, and X is specifically used to indicate their safety during pregnancy, helping healthcare providers to make informed decisions about medication use in pregnant patients.

questions.text: Match the Following hormones to receptors: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-D

 

  1. Insulin - Tyrosine Kinase Pathway: Insulin uses a tyrosine kinase receptor. This is a cell surface receptor that, when activated, phosphorylates tyrosine residues on target proteins, triggering intracellular signaling cascades.
  2. Growth Hormone - JAK-STAT Pathway: Growth hormone, along with prolactin and leptin, uses the JAK-STAT (Janus Kinase-Signal Transducer and Activator of Transcription) pathway. This is a cytokine receptor-mediated signaling mechanism.
  3. Acetylcholine - Ligand-gated Channel: At the neuromuscular junction, acetylcholine operates through ligand-gated sodium channels. When acetylcholine binds, these channels open, allowing sodium ions to flow and triggering muscle contraction.
  4. Levothyroxine (Thyroid Hormone) - Nuclear Receptor: Thyroid hormones act through nuclear receptors, which means they enter the cell and directly interact with DNA in the nucleus to regulate gene expression.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Classification of Receptors

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient visits his family practitioner for a yearly examination. On examination, his BP was 190/100 mm Hg. His pulse pressure was 90 mm Hg. What would have decreased resulting in this increase in pulse pressure?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Arterial wall compliance

 

Pulse pressure is the difference between systolic and diastolic blood pressure, and it reflects the compliance (elasticity) of the arterial walls. In this scenario, the patient has a high systolic blood pressure and a normal diastolic blood pressure, resulting in an increased pulse pressure of 90 mm Hg (190 mm Hg - 100 mm Hg = 90 mm Hg).

 

Arterial wall compliance refers to the ability of the arteries to expand and contract with each heartbeat, which helps maintain a steady blood pressure. Decreased arterial wall compliance leads to increased stiffness of the arteries, which can cause an increase in systolic blood pressure and pulse pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myocardial contractility: Incorrect. While myocardial contractility can influence blood pressure, it is not directly related to the increase in pulse pressure in this scenario.

 

Option B. Stroke volume: Incorrect. Stroke volume affects cardiac output and overall blood pressure but is not the primary factor in the increase in pulse pressure observed here.

 

Option D. Cardiac output: Incorrect. Cardiac output can affect overall blood pressure, but the specific increase in pulse pressure in this case is more closely linked to decreased arterial wall compliance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased arterial wall compliance leads to increased stiffness of the arteries, resulting in higher systolic blood pressure and an increased pulse pressure, as observed in the patient.

questions.text: Identify the marked area in the given spirometry graph?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Functional residual capacity

 

Explanation:

 

The marked area in the spirometry graph indicates the Functional Residual Capacity (FRC). FRC is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal, passive exhalation. This is not fully expelled during a standard tidal cycle and represents the air that remains in the lungs to keep them inflated.

 

  • FRC Components:
    • FRC includes the Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) plus the Residual Volume (RV).
    • ERV is the additional air that can be forcibly exhaled after the end of a normal, calm exhalation.
    • RV is the volume of air still remaining in the lungs after the most forceful exhalation, which cannot be voluntarily expelled.

 

 

Significance in Spirometry:

 

In spirometry:

 

  • FRC is critical for maintaining the alveolar inflation and preventing the airways from collapsing.
  • It is not directly measurable by simple spirometry because it includes the residual volume. Techniques such as body plethysmography or using tracer gas dilution methods are usually employed to measure FRC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tidal Volume (TV or VT): This is the volume of air inhaled or exhaled during a normal breathing cycle, not indicated in this context.

 

Option C. Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV): Part of FRC, this is the maximum volume of air that can be voluntarily expelled after the end of a normal, passive exhalation.

 

Option D. Expiratory Capacity: It is the total amount of air that can be expired from the lungs after a maximal inhalation, typically including the tidal volume plus the expiratory reserve volume, not specifically marked here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal expiration and is essential for preventing lung collapse and maintaining pulmonary function, especially during physical activities or respiratory challenges. Understanding FRC's role helps in assessing lung health and diagnosing potential respiratory disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following jugular venous pressure (JVP) waves corresponds to the isovolumetric contraction phase of the cardiac cycle? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) c wave

 

The jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform consists of multiple waves that correspond to different phases of the cardiac cycle.

 

The "c" wave corresponds to the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular contraction, causing a brief increase in pressure in the right atrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The "a" wave corresponds to the atrial contraction, which occurs during the late ventricular filling phase of the cardiac cycle. This is the period before the closure of the mitral/ tricuspid valve. The "a" wave is caused by the contraction of the atrium, leading to a brief increase in right atrial pressure.

 

Option C. The "x" descent corresponds to the returning of the tricuspid valve to its normal position during ventricular contraction (i.e. ejection) and atrial relaxation.

 

Option D. The "y" descent corresponds to the rapid emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle during ventricular diastole.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "c" wave of the jugular venous pressure waveform corresponds to the isovolumetric contraction phase of the cardiac cycle, reflecting the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium as the right ventricle begins to contract.

choices.text: Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus
Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
Abductor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis

questions.text: Which of the following forms the lateral boundary of the anatomical snuff box? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus

 

The anatomical snuffbox is a triangular depression located on the lateral aspect of the wrist and the base of the thumb. When the thumb is extended, this depression becomes more pronounced. The lateral boundary of the anatomical snuff box is formed by extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus. When you extend and abduct the thumb, you can typically feel these tendons, especially the abductor pollicis longus, become taut along the lateral border of the wrist, outlining the snuffbox.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis: The extensor pollicis longus forms the medial boundary of the anatomical snuffbox. It extends the thumb's distal phalanx. The abductor pollicis brevis is a muscle of the thenar eminence and doesn't directly contribute to the boundaries of the anatomical snuffbox. Its tendon is not found in this region; instead, it inserts into the base of the thumb's proximal phalanx.
