Option C. Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis: As already mentioned, the extensor pollicis longus forms the medial boundary of the anatomical snuffbox. The extensor pollicis brevis, in conjunction with the abductor pollicis longus, forms the lateral boundary. However, they don't together form just one boundary of the snuffbox.

 

Option D. Abductor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis: The abductor pollicis longus contributes to the lateral boundary of the snuffbox, as mentioned above. The abductor pollicis brevis, on the other hand, doesn't form any part of the snuffbox boundaries.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: To prevent teratogenic effects
To avoid failure of ATT
Because rifampicin can decrease OCP metabolism
Because rifampicin can induce OCP metabolism and cause failure

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient has been diagnosed with tuberculosis and is about to begin antitubercular therapy (ATT) that includes rifampicin. She is currently taking oral contraceptives (OCP) for birth control. The clinician advises her to use an additional barrier method of contraception while undergoing treatment. What is the primary reason for this recommendation? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Because rifampicin can induce OCP metabolism and cause failure

 

Rifampicin is used as one of the first line drugs against tuberculosis. Rifampicin is an enzyme inducer, that induces the cytochrome P450 enzymes. Therefore, this leads to increased rate of metabolism of the OCPs, thereby leading to contraceptive failure. So, in a female receiving ATT, it is advised to use additional barrier methods of contraception apart from OCPs.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. To prevent teratogenic effects: Most of the antitubercular drugs including rifampicin, isoniazid and ethambutol are safe in pregnancy. Further she is already taking OCPs, so the examiner does not want to ask about teratogenic effect of antitubercular drugs.

 

Option B. To avoid failure of ATT: The interaction between ATT and OCP does not lead to the failure of antitubercular therapy; rather, it affects the efficacy of the oral contraceptive method.

 

Option C. Because rifampicin can decrease OCP metabolism: This is incorrect because rifampicin actually induces, rather than decreases, the metabolism of oral contraceptives. This can lead to reduced levels of contraceptive hormones in the blood, thereby potentially leading to contraceptive failure.

 

Educational Objective

 

Rifampicin is known to induce hepatic enzymes that speed up the metabolism of various drugs, including oral contraceptives. This can lead to lower blood levels of the hormones in OCPs, thereby reducing their efficacy and increasing the risk of contraceptive failure. Hence, it is advised for patients on both medications to use an additional barrier method of contraception.

choices.text: Calcium channel blockers

questions.text: Urinary alkalinization will be most useful in toxicity of which of the following drugs? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Aspirin
 

Urinary alkalinization is a key treatment in aspirin toxicity. Aspirin (salicylate) is a weak acid, and alkalinizing the urine increases the ionization of salicylates. This ionization traps salicylates in the urine, preventing their reabsorption and enhancing their elimination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta blockers: Urinary alkalinization is not a standard treatment for beta blocker toxicity. Management of beta blocker overdose typically involves supportive care and, in severe cases, specific antidotes like glucagon or high-dose insulin.

 

Option B. Calcium channel blockers: Similar to beta blockers, urinary alkalinization is not a primary treatment for calcium channel blocker overdose. Treatment often includes calcium infusions, glucagon, and other supportive measures.

 

Option C. Acetaminophen: For acetaminophen toxicity, the antidote N-acetylcysteine (NAC) is used. Urinary alkalinization is not effective for acetaminophen overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urinary alkalinization is most useful in the treatment of aspirin (salicylate) toxicity because it increases the elimination of salicylates by trapping them in the urine through ionization. This method is not effective for beta blockers, calcium channel blockers, or acetaminophen toxicity.

questions.text: Match the following muscles with their action at shoulder joint: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

 

A. Latissimus dorsi: This muscle is known as the "stand at ease" muscle, the "climbers muscle," and the "swimmers muscle." It originates from the back and inserts into the front between two major muscles. When it contracts, it causes backward movement, extension, adduction, and medial rotation of the shoulder. Therefore, its action is extension with medial rotation (Action 2).

 

B. Supraspinatus: Located above the spine of the scapula, the supraspinatus muscle, when it contracts, moves the arm away from the midline, which is known as abduction. Hence, its action is abduction (Action 3).

 

C. Infraspinatus: This muscle originates from the back and rotates the arm outward when it contracts, causing lateral rotation. Thus, its action is lateral rotation (Action 4).

 

D. Pectoralis Major (sternal head): Originating from the midline (sternum and clavicle) and inserting into the lateral lip of the intertubercular sulcus, this muscle, when contracted, causes movement to the front (flexion). Therefore, its action is flexion (Action 1).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Latissimus dorsi is responsible for extension with medial rotation.
  • Supraspinatus is responsible for abduction.
  • Infraspinatus is responsible for lateral rotation.
  • Pectoralis Major (sternal head) is responsible for flexion.

questions.text: Which of the following drug binds to CD4 receptors and is used for both CCR-5 as well as CXCR-4 tropic HIV? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ibalizumab

 

Explanation: 


Ibalizumab is a post-attachment inhibitor that binds to CD4 receptors. After HIV attaches to CD4 via GP120, ibalizumab prevents the conformational change in the CD4 receptor that is necessary for viral entry. Since it acts directly on CD4 receptors, it is effective against both CCR5 and CXCR4-tropic HIV strains.


Entry Inhibitors

 

 

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Maraviroc: This is a CCR5 co-receptor antagonist. It only works against CCR5-tropic HIV and is ineffective against CXCR4-tropic strains.

 

Option C. Fostemsavir: This is an attachment inhibitor that binds to viral GP120, preventing initial attachment to CD4 receptors. It does not bind to CD4 receptors directly.

 

Option D. Tenofovir: This is a Nucleotide Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitor (NRTI). It works after viral entry by inhibiting viral DNA synthesis. It does not affect viral entry or bind to CD4 receptors.

 

Educational Objective: 


Ibalizumab is a post-attachment inhibitor that binds to CD4 receptors and prevents HIV from entering T-cells by inhibiting conformational changes required for interaction with CCR5 and CXCR4 co-receptors. It is useful in multidrug-resistant HIV cases where other entry inhibitors like Maraviroc (CCR5-specific) are ineffective.

choices.text: Opening of calcium channels

questions.text: According to myogenic hypothesis of renal autoregulation, the afferent arterioles contract in response to stretch-induced by? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Opening of calcium channels

 

Explanation

 

Renal autoregulation is important to maintain the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Blood flow to kidneys remains normal even when the mean arterial blood pressure varies widely between 60 mm Hg and 180 mm Hg. This helps to maintain normal GFR.

 

Two mechanisms are involved in renal autoregulation:

 

  1. Myogenic response
  2. Tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF)

 

1. MYOGENIC RESPONSE

 

Whenever, the blood flow to kidneys increases,  →  stretches the elastic wall of the afferent arteriole →  Stretching of the vessel wall increases the flow of calcium ions from extracellular fluid into the cells →  The influx of calcium ions leads to the contraction of smooth muscles in afferent arteriole, which causes constriction of afferent arteriole →  So, the blood flow is decreased.

 

 

2. TGF

 

The macula densa, a plaque of specialized tubular epithelial cells located in the distal tubule, monitors the NaCl concentration of the tubular fluid and sends an as of yet unidentified signal to control glomerular hemodynamics. In this mechanism, called tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF), an increase in NaCl concentration at the macula densa constricts the glomerular afferent arteriole and thus decreases the single-nephron GFR. Along with the myogenic response, TGF significantly contributes to renal autoregulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NO: Incorrect, as nitric oxide generally causes vasodilation, not the contraction associated with the myogenic response.

 

Option B. Noradrenaline: Incorrect, although noradrenaline can affect blood vessel tone, it is not directly involved in the myogenic response mechanism of renal autoregulation.

 

Option D. Adenosine: Incorrect, adenosine is more involved in tubuloglomerular feedback rather than the myogenic mechanism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In renal autoregulation, the myogenic hypothesis states that the afferent arterioles contract in response to increased blood pressure, which stretches the arteriole walls. This contraction is mediated by the opening of calcium channels, leading to an influx of calcium ions and subsequent constriction of the arteriole, thereby helping to stabilize GFR across varying blood pressures.
